conclusion: Let’s dive into this physics problem step by step, analyzing the system of springs, pulley, and mass to find the height that object \( A \) rises and the spring constant \( k_2 \) of spring \( C \). The setup involves a mass \( A \) suspended between two springs, with a pulley and rope system, and we’re given specific conditions about forces at equilibrium.

We have: - Mass \( A \) with mass \( m = 2 \, \text{kg} \). - Spring \( B \) (vertical) with spring constant \( k_1 = 200 \, \text{N/m} \), its lower end fixed to the ground. - Spring \( C \) (horizontal) with spring constant \( k_2 \) (to be determined), connected via a thin rope over a fixed pulley to mass \( A \). - Initially, spring \( C \) is at its natural length, with its right endpoint at position \( a \), and the rope connecting \( A \) to the pulley is vertical. - The right endpoint of spring \( C \) is pulled horizontally from position \( a \) to position \( b \), a distance \( ab = 60 \, \text{cm} = 0.6 \, \text{m}. - At position \( b \), the tension in spring \( B \) equals the gravitational force on \( A \).

Gravitational force on \( A \): \[ mg = 2 \times 9.8 = 19.6 \, \text{N}, \] assuming \( g = 9.8 \, \text{m/s}^2 \). The condition at position \( b \): the force exerted by spring \( B \) on \( A \) (upward) equals \( mg = 19.6 \, \text{N}.

premise: At equilibrium, the force from spring \( B \) (upward) balances \( mg \) (downward): \[ k_1 x_0 = mg, \] where \( x_0 \) is the initial extension of spring \( B \).
conclusion: Initial stretch of spring \( B \): \[ x_0 = \frac{mg}{k_1} = \frac{19.6}{200} = 0.098 \, \text{m} = 9.8 \, \text{cm}. \] So, initially, spring \( B \) is stretched by 9.8 cm.

premise: When the right end of spring \( C \) is at position \( b \), the problem states that the tension in spring \( B \) equals \( mg \). The force from spring \( B \) is: \[ F_B = k_1 x, \] where \( x \) is the extension of spring \( B \) at this point.
conclusion: Final stretch of spring \( B \): \[ k_1 x = 19.6 \implies 200 x = 19.6 \implies x = 0.098 \, \text{m}. \] Interestingly, the extension of spring \( B \) remains 9.8 cm, the same as the initial state.

premise: If the natural length of spring \( B \) is \( L_B \), then: \[ y_0 = L_B + x_0 = L_B + 0.098. \] When spring \( C \)’s end is pulled to position \( b \), mass \( A \) moves to a new height \( y \), and spring \( B \)’s extension becomes \( x \): \[ x = y - L_B. \] But we found \( x = 0.098 \, \text{m}
